boolean.comment: The `boolean` function can coerce a truthy value to `java.lang.Boolean`.
boolean.name: Boolean

signed_integer_16_bit.comment: The `short` function can coerce a a numeric value to `java.lang.Short`.
signed_integer_16_bit.name: Signed 16-bit integer

signed_integer_32_bit.comment: Clojure cannot directly instantiate primitive `int`, but it can be used as a type hint.
signed_integer_32_bit.name: Signed 32-bit integer

signed_integer_64_bit.comment: The `long` function can coerce a a numeric value to `java.lang.Long`. Note the default type for literal numeric integrals is already long.
signed_integer_64_bit.name: Signed 64-bit integer

signed_integer_as_object.comment: The `int` function can coerce a a numeric value to `java.lang.Integer`.
signed_integer_as_object.name: Signed object-based Integer

signed_float_32_bit.comment: Clojure cannot directly instantiate primitive `float`, but it can be used as a type hint.
signed_float_32_bit.name: Signed 32-bit floating point

signed_float_64_bit.comment: The `double` function can coerce a numeric value to java.lang.Double.
signed_float_64_bit.name: Signed 64-bit floating point

signed_float_as_object.comment: The `float` function can coerce a a numeric value to `java.lang.Float`.
signed_float_as_object.name: Signed object-based floating point

string_as_object.comment: `java.lang.String` literals can be used directly, and the `str` function can be used to build a string out of concatenated calls to `.toString` of its arguments.
string_as_object.name: String as an object

string_as_array.name: String as an array of characters
